user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_header:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_add_response_header (struct MHD_Response *response,
                         const char *header,
                         const char *content)
{
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONNECTION))
    return add_response_header_connection (response, content);

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_TRANSFER_ENCODING))
  {
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (content, "chunked"))
      return MHD_NO;   /* Only "chunked" encoding is allowed */
    if (0 != (response->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED))
      return MHD_YES;  /* Already has "chunked" encoding header */
    if ( (0 != (response->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)) &&
         (0 == (MHD_RF_INSANITY_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH & response->flags)) )
      return MHD_NO; /* Has "Content-Length" header and no "Insanity" flag */
    if (MHD_NO != add_response_entry (response,
                                      MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                      header,
                                      content))
    {
      response->flags_auto |= MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED;
      return MHD_YES;
    }
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE))
  {
    if (0 != (response->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_DATE_HDR))
    {
      struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;
      hdr = MHD_get_response_element_n_ (response, MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                         MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE,
                                         MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                           MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE));
      mhd_assert (NULL != hdr);
      _MHD_remove_header (response, hdr);
      if (NULL != hdr->value)
        free (hdr->value);
      free (hdr->header);
      free (hdr);
    }
    if (MHD_NO != add_response_entry (response,
                                      MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                      header,
                                      content))
    {
      response->flags_auto |= MHD_RAF_HAS_DATE_HDR;
      return MHD_YES;
    }
    return MHD_NO;
  }

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_ (header,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH))
  {
    /* Generally MHD sets automatically correct "Content-Length" always when
     * needed.
     * Custom "Content-Length" header is allowed only in special cases. */
    if ( (0 != (MHD_RF_INSANITY_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH & response->flags)) ||
         ((0 != (MHD_RF_HEAD_ONLY_RESPONSE & response->flags)) &&
          (0 == (response->flags_auto & (MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED
                                         | MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)))) )
    {
      if (MHD_NO != add_response_entry (response,
                                        MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                        header,
                                        content))
      {
        response->flags_auto |= MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH;
        return MHD_YES;
      }
    }
    return MHD_NO;
  }

  return add_response_entry (response,
                             MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                             header,
                             content);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
hdr = MHD_get_response_element_n_ (response, MHD_HEADER_KIND,
                                         MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE,
                                         MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                           MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment itself does not call any <string.h> routines and passes a compile‑time length computed from the static header name macro (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE)). Provided that MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ expands to the actual number of characters in the literal (typically sizeof("Date")-1) and that MHD_get_response_element_n_ uses that length to compare only that many bytes (rather than attempting to read a larger/unknown length from the stored header), there is no out‑of‑bounds access and Rule 21.17 is not violated. A concrete violation scenario would be if MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ returned a length larger than the allocated/stored header buffer (for example including an extra byte) or if MHD_get_response_element_n_ internally calls a string function (e.g. strlen/strcpy/strcmp) that reads past the stored header buffer; in that case accesses beyond the bounds could occur and Rule 21.17 would be violated.
